#Text=CHAPTER 21
#Text=“ Well , ” said one of the deputies , as he backed the horse into the shafts of the buggy in which the pursuers had driven over from the Hill , “ we 've about as good as got him .
#Text=It is n't hard to follow a man who carries a bird cage with him wherever he goes . ”
#Text=McTeague crossed the mountains on foot the Friday and Saturday of that week , going over through Emigrant Gap , following the line of the Overland railroad .
#Text=He reached Reno Monday night .
#Text=By degrees a vague plan of action outlined itself in the dentist 's mind .
#Text=“ Mexico , ” he muttered to himself .
#Text=“ Mexico , that 's the place .
#Text=They 'll watch the coast and they 'll watch the Eastern trains , but they wo n't think of Mexico . ”
#Text=The sense of pursuit which had harassed him during the last week of his stay at the Big Dipper mine had worn off , and he believed himself to be very cunning .
#Text=“ I 'm pretty far ahead now , I guess , ” he said .
#Text=At Reno he boarded a south-bound freight on the line of the Carson and Colorado railroad , paying for a passage in the caboose .
#Text=“ Freights don ' run on schedule time , ” he muttered , “ and a conductor on a passenger train makes it his business to study faces .
#Text=I 'll stay with this train as far as it goes . ”
#Text=The freight worked slowly southward , through western Nevada , the country becoming hourly more and more desolate and abandoned .
#Text=After leaving Walker Lake the sage-brush country began , and the freight rolled heavily over tracks that threw off visible layers of heat .
#Text=At times it stopped whole half days on sidings or by water tanks , and the engineer and fireman came back to the caboose and played poker with the conductor and train crew .
#Text=The dentist sat apart , behind the stove , smoking pipe after pipe of cheap tobacco .
#Text=Sometimes he joined in the poker games .

#Text=He had learned poker when a boy at the mine , and after a few deals his knowledge returned to him ; but for the most part he was taciturn and unsociable , and rarely spoke to the others unless spoken to first .
#Text=The crew recognized the type , and the impression gained ground among them that he had “ done for ” a livery-stable keeper at Truckee and was trying to get down into Arizona .
#Text=McTeague heard two brakemen discussing him one night as they stood outside by the halted train .
#Text=“ The livery-stable keeper called him a bastard ; that 's what Picachos told me , ” one of them remarked , “ and started to draw his gun ; an ' this fellar did for him with a hayfork .
#Text=He 's a horse doctor , this chap is , and the livery-stable keeper had got the law on him so 's he could n't practise any more , an ' he was sore about it . ”
#Text=Near a place called Queen 's the train reentered California , and McTeague observed with relief that the line of track which had hitherto held westward curved sharply to the south again .

#Text=The train was unmolested ; occasionally the crew fought with a gang of tramps who attempted to ride the brake beams , and once in the northern part of Inyo County , while they were halted at a water tank , an immense Indian buck , blanketed to the ground , approached McTeague as he stood on the roadbed stretching his legs , and without a word presented to him a filthy , crumpled letter .
#Text=The letter was to the effect that the buck Big Jim was a good Indian and deserving of charity ; the signature was illegible .
#Text=The dentist stared at the letter , returned it to the buck , and regained the train just as it started .

#Text=Neither had spoken ; the buck did not move from his position , and fully five minutes afterward , when the slow-moving freight was miles away , the dentist looked back and saw him still standing motionless between the rails , a forlorn and solitary point of red , lost in the immensity of the surrounding white blur of the desert .
#Text=At length the mountains began again , rising up on either side of the track ; vast , naked hills of white sand and red rock , spotted with blue shadows .
#Text=Here and there a patch of green was spread like a gay table-cloth over the sand .
#Text=All at once Mount Whitney leaped over the horizon .
#Text=Independence was reached and passed ; the freight , nearly emptied by now , and much shortened , rolled along the shores of Owen Lake .
#Text=At a place called Keeler it stopped definitely .
#Text=It was the terminus of the road .
#Text=The town of Keeler was a one-street town , not unlike Iowa Hill -- the post-office , the bar and hotel , the Odd Fellows ' Hall , and the livery stable being the principal buildings .
#Text=“ Where to now ? ” muttered McTeague to himself as he sat on the edge of the bed in his room in the hotel .
#Text=He hung the canary in the window , filled its little bathtub , and watched it take its bath with enormous satisfaction .
#Text=“ Where to now ? ” he muttered again .
#Text=“ This is as far as the railroad goes , an ' it won ' do for me to stay in a town yet a while ;
#Text=no , it won ' do .
#Text=I got to clear out .
#Text=Where to ?
#Text=That 's the word , where to ?
#Text=I 'll go down to supper now” -- He went on whispering his thoughts aloud , so that they would take more concrete shape in his mind --
#Text=“I 'll go down to supper now , an ' then I 'll hang aroun ' the bar this evening till I get the lay of this land .
#Text=Maybe this is fruit country , though it looks more like a cattle country .
#Text=Maybe it 's a mining country .

#Text=If it 's a mining country , ” he continued , puckering his heavy eyebrows , “ if it 's a mining country , an ' the mines are far enough off the roads , maybe I 'd better get to the mines an ' lay quiet for a month before I try to get any farther south . ”
